UNEMPLOYMENT INSURANCE.(Reference Cabinet 4.1 (30) Conclusion 5 (a) .)Note by the Minister of Labour, covering Reportof the Advisory (Three Party) Committee onUnemployment Insurance.(CP. yjbr (30) - already circulated).Memorandum by the Minister of Labour, givingillustrative Bases of claims to Unemployment benefit by married women, seasonal workers, short-timeworkers, etc.(CP. 381 (30) - to be circulated).Note by the Minister of Labour, covering draftof Unemployment Insurance Bill.(CP. 373 (30) - to be circulated).Memorandum by the Minister of Labour on UhemploymentInsurance for the Agricultural Industry.(CP. 382 (30) - to be circulated).3. DYESTUFFS (IMPORT REGULATION) ACT. 1920.(Reference Cabinet 65 (30) Conclusion 6 and cabinet 66 (JO) Conclusion 14).Memorandum by the President of the Board of Trade.(CP. 341 (30) - already circulated).Further Memorandum by the President of the Boardof Trade.(CP. 375 (3C - already circulated). 5- LIGHTHOUSES IN IRELAND.Memorandum by the President of the Board of Trade,(CP. 576 (30) - already circulated).Memorandum by the Secretary of State for HomeAffairs.(CP. 3/9 (30) - to be circulated)..m6- KING'S ROLL; APPLICATION FROM RUSSIAN OIL PRODUCTS.LTD.(Reference Cabinet GG (30) Conclusion 11).Memorandum by the Minister of Labour.(CP. 373 (30) - already circulated).Memorandum by the Secretary of State for HomeAffairs and the Minister of Labour.(CP. 330 (30) - to be circulated).7. Oopy No..G A B.I N E T 68 (50).CONCLUSIONS of a Meeting of the Cabinet heldin the Prime Minister's Room, House ofCommons, S.W.1., on MONDAY, 17thNovember, 1920, at 8.0 p.m.PRESENT:-The Right Hon. J. Ramsay MacDonald, M.P.,Prime Minister. (in the Chair).IThe Right Hon.Philip Snowden, M.P.,Chancellor of theExchequer.jThe .Right Hon..J.H. Thomas, M.P.,Secretary of State forDominion Affairs.fine Right Hon.Lord Parmoor of Frieth,k.c.y.0..k.g.lord president of the Council.JThe Right Hon.J.R. 'George Lansbury, M.P.,-First Commissioner ofWorks. -Colonel Sir M,.P.Ai Hahkey, G.C.B. ,G. C.M.G. ..... Secretary. 1. The communication.net had before them the following papers by the Minister of Labour on the subjectof Unemployment Insurance:-A note (CP.-374 (30)) covering the Report of the Advisory (Three-Party) Committee on UnemploymentInsurance, which had been beforethe Cabinet at the Meeting referredto in the margin:A Memorandum (CP.-381 (30))giving illustrative oases of claims to Unemployment Benefit by marriedwomen, seasonal workers, short-timeworkers, etc,A Note (CP.-378 (30)) covering-draft of Unemployment insurance bill:A Memorandum (CP .-382 ( 30)) onUnemployment Insurance for theAgricultural Industry/together withA Memorandum by the Minister ofAgriculture and Fisheries(C.P.-384 (30)) containingcomments and suggestions inrelation to the minister^ Labour's Memorandum (C.P.-382 (30)) on the subject ofUnemployment Insurance for theAgricultural Industry .The Minister of Labour informed the Cabinetthat she had not yet been able to obtain fromthe leaders of the Liberal Party any reply asto their attitude towards the UnemploymentInsurance (No,-t) Bill. She had just learned,that they would not consider the subject before-Wednesday, November 19th. This would probablynecessitate some delay in the introduction.ofthe BillVv She also informed the Cabinet of communications she had had with representativesof the General Council o^ the Trades UnionCongress, who had stated that if the Governmentdesired, to consult thai, they should do so inwriting. The Cabinet agreed - 320(a) That the Minister of labour should proceed as rapidly aspossible with the setting upof the Royal Commission onUnemployment Insurance:(b) That, in doing so, she should endeavour to secure theservioes of the Chairman whose.,name was propos ed by theChancellor of the Exchequerduring the Cabinet Meeting,and of the members submittedby her and approved by theCabinet: -(c) That the Minister of labour should, in addition, i&vitethe General Council of theTrades Union Congress and the/4fcA^6 Cn$^***Ji**.IC^4^-xa4^&ttr^ British- Indust-vxoSyZ^U^y^ito nominate each a member of the^W^^/i^-.Royal Commission: - -(d) That there should be no specialrepresentatives for territorial divisions of the United Kingdom,e,g ., Scotland, Wales, or London:(e) That the Minister of Labour shouldcontinue to urge the Leaders ofthe Liberal Party to define theirattitude in regard'to the Bill assoon as possible, and, in particular,should, impress upon them that theintention of the Government is thatthe Royal Commission should be aemail one, working expeditiouslyand rendering Interim Reports as3oon as possible. She should have authority, if she deemed advisable,to inform them of the proposedcomposibion of the Royal Commission:(f) That, as soon as she has reached agreement with the Leaders of theLiberal Party, the Minister ofLabour should arrange with theParliamentary Secretary to theTreasury.for the introduction'of the Bill at the earliestpossible date:(g) That, in accordance with herproposal in C.P,-382 (30)) inregard to the extension ofUnemployment Insurance to theAgricultural Industry, theMinister of Labour in the forth-coming Debate in parliament should express sympathy with theobject of the Motion Gallingattention to this question, andshould s-y that as the scope of the National Scheme is one ofthe subjects that will beconsidered by the RoyalCommission, the question ofthe inclusion of Agriculturemust then arise. Pending suchconsideration by the Cormnissionit would be premature to cometo a decision. bpfect opLonged tjn-few7. to^TH INSUR-1 ANDfcfr' AND OLDI pFNSItNS .lev i cmsJference:pbinet 6 5lO),. Con-fusion 7 .)S. The Cabinet again had -under consideration a Memorandum by the Minister of Health (CP.-551.(3Q)) in regard to the effect of prolonged unemployment on the title to Health insurance and Widows' and Old Age Pensions, which hadbeen before them at the Meeting mentioned inthe margin.After the Minister of Health and theChancellor of the "Exchequer had reported theresults of the consultations which they andthe Secretary of State for Scotland had carriedout in regard to this subject, the cabinet agreed To adopt the second alternativesuggested in CP.-351 (30), viz,:-"To continue insurance untilthe 31st December, 19 31, for pension purposes only, with no title to any HealthInsurance benefits". * 9 oo i* aIpypSTUFFS 3. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandum byort RFGU-0!jj ACT, the President of the Board o^ Trade (C .P .-375 ( 30))in regard to the Dyestuffs (import Regulation) Act,viouserenoe: 1920, stating that in accordance with the requestinet 66) Con- o^ his colleagues (Cabinet 65 (BO), Conclusion 6)ion14.)he had met representatives of the following organ-isations:-The Federation of Master Cotton Spinners'Associations,The Cotton Spinners' and Manufacturers'Associations,The Woollen and Worsted Trades Federation,andThe Worsted Spinners' Federation, ;. -The United Textile Factory Workers' Association.The Amalgamated leavers' Association.The representatives present had stated definitely that they were satisfied that the official attitudeof opposition to the Dyestuffs Act which the aboveorganisations had always taken up was still main-tained and had the continued support of the greatmajority of the members. They thereforeopposed any prolongation of the Act, for reasons which the President of the Board of Trade .eet outin his Memorandum.Gn a careful examination of the whole question from the point of view not only of the Dye industry but also o^ the important industries in Lancashire,Yorkshire and elsewhere, which use dyes, the Cabinet.agreed (a) That the Dyestuffs (import Regulation)Act, 1920, should not be renewed:(b) That in announcing this inthe House of Commons the Presidentof the Board of Trade should make clear that in reaching their decision the Cabinet have had regard to the'industrial condition of the countryand should refer specifically to theLancashire and. Yorkshire industries . ;Htr EDUCATIONgOHOOL ATTEND-and) BILL,930,.previous ousRefer enc e:Cabinet 65.(30), Oon-clu3ion 6.)4. The President of the Board of Educationreported that he had not yet been able to ascertain from the Leaders of the Liberal Party what theirattitude was, towards the Bill. He warned hiscolleagues, however, that it might become un-avoid-able to postpone ^or a year the date at which theAct would come into operation.A^ter considering the position of the Billin the light of othe-* Government business, theCabinet agreed (a) That the President of the Boardof Education should continue topress the Liberals to define theirat attitude:(b) That he should prepare a programme for the further stages of the Billin Comm. it tee and in Parliament, fordiscussion with the Prime Minister:(c) That, subject to agreement with thePrime Minister and to this procedurebeing deemed advisable, a guillotineMotion should be introduced in committee during the following week. JS EDUCATIONISOHOOL ATTEND-fiJNCF) BILL,M5Q .HreviousReference:Cabinet 63-(30), Con-elusion 6.)4. The President of the Board of Educationreported that he had not yet been able to ascertain from the Leaders o^ the Liberal Party what theirattitude was. towards the Bill. He warned hiscolleagues, however, that it might become turavoid-able to postpone ^or a year the date at which theAct would come into operation.A^ter considering the position of the Billin the light of othe^ Government business, theCabinet agreed (a) That the President of the Boardof Fducation should continue topress the Liberals to define theirattitude:(b) That he should prepare a programme for the further stages of the Billin Committee and in Parliament, fordiscussion with the Prime Minister:(c) That, subject to agreement with thePrime Minister and to this procedurebeing deemed advisable, a guillotineM-otion should be introduced in committee during the following week. 5. In the course of the discussion referredto in the preceding Minute, references were madeto the general state of the G-ov ernmcnt' s business in Parliament. In regard to the Land ValuationBill the Chancellor of the Exchequer reported that conversations with leading Liberals and supporters of the Government indicated a preference 'or theplan of incorporating the provisions of the LandValuation Bill In the next Budget.Attention was drawn to the difficulty inobtaining from the Liberal Leaders a timelyexpression of their attitude towards Bills to beintroduced by the Government, The Trade disputes and Trades Unions Bill was quoted as an example.It was suggested that the task of Ministers wouldbe facilitated if, instead o^ consultation inregard to each Bill, sore general understandingcould he reached. In this connection it waspointed out, however, that before ary generalarrangement could be made, the Liberals wouldrequire an understanding in regard to electoral reform, and on this subject they had. not definedtheir attitude.The Prime minister"" informed his colleagues that, in consultation with the parliamentary secretary to the Treasury, he was reviewing thestate of Par liars ent ary business. (IRELAND . lous es an.-6. The Cabinet, had before them Memoranda bythe President of the Board of Trade (CP.-376 -(30)) and the Home. Secretary (CP.-379 (3,0)) onthe subject of the administration o* IrishLights.The Home Secretary reported that he and thePresident of the Board of Trade were likely tocome to an agreement on this subject in theiro ijo e d i a t e f ut ur e .On the suggestion of the President of theBoard of Trade, the Cabinet agreed That the question should be postponed for a. week. king'S 7 . The Cabinet again had before them a Mems--randum by the Minister of Labour (CP .-37 3 (30))Rational Schemew0r Disabled in regard to a renewed application from RussianIx-Servicemen. *il Products, Limited, for enrolment on the Eing'application Roll for Disabled ex-Service Menr together with a[from Russianffiil Products, Joint Memorandum by the Home Secretary and theiLimited.Minister of Labour (0.P.-3S0 (30)) stating that(Previous further enquiries had indicated that recentReference:Satinet 66 staff changes in the Company had not shown any(30), Con-clusion 11.) striking tendency towards the replacement ofBritish subjects by Russians, and that it has.beena long-established arrangement that Ministry ofLabour permits are not issued in cases whereRussians come to this country to join the company or other Soviet commercial undertakings .The Cabinet agreed -That the Russian Gil Products,Limited, should not be includedon the King's Roll. THE BRITISH S. The Cabinet had under consideration theBEER BILL.British Beer Bill, to be introduced by a Private(Previous Member in the House of Commons on Friday, NovemberReference:Cabinet 10 21st.(30), Con-conclusion 12.) The Cabinet agreed That the Minister of Agricultureand Fisheries should make clearthat the Bill could receive no support or facilities from theGov ernment. ?j the local 9 . The Cabinet had before them the LocalAUTHORITIES(PUBLICITY) Authorities (Publicity) Bill, to be introducedBILL.in the House of Commons by a Private Member on(Previous Friday, November 21st.Reference:Cabinet 17 The Cabinet agreed (30) , Con-elusion 9(b).) That the Minister of health should be authorised to give general support to the principleof the Bill, but should exercisecaution in promising facilities.He should make it clear that onlyin the event of a Bill agreed byall Parties, which would notencounter any opposition what a o-ever, might it be possible later in the Session for the Governmentto give facilities. 10. The Cabinet had tef oro / a Note by thePresident of the Board of Trade (C.P.-383 (3C))covering a Memorandum by the Secretary for Mineson the National Industrial Board. In thisMemorandum the Secretary ^or Mines reported a difficulty which had arisen in putting in force the Coal Mines Act, 1930, owing to the refusal of the four bodies of employers conoerned toco-operate in nominating representatives for the goal Mines National Industrial Board, ThePresident of the Board of Trade reported that hehad authorised the Secretary fo1- Mines to endeavourto fill the two places on which the Federation ofBritish Industries, the Association of chambers of Commerce and the Confederation of Employers'Organisations have to be consulted, as well as toinclude in the Board any coal-owners who may be nominated by Yorkshire, and thus to proceed withthe constitution o^ the Board even though theother coal-owners refused to nominate representa-tives .The Cabinet were urged to give furtherconsideration to this question in the light ofthe industrial outlook as affecting not onlythe Mines but also the Railways, and the Presidentof the Board of Trade was asked to postpone for afe1- days the action he had sanctioned by theSecretary for Mines as set ^orth above.The Cabinet agreed (a) That the question should be consideredby a Cabinet Committee, composed asfollows -The Lo-d Privy Seal,The Secretary of State forDominion Affairs,The President of the Board of Trade,The Secretary for Mines - which arranged to meet on tuesday, November 18th, at p.m,,, in the House of Commons;(b) That the subject should beplaced on the Agenda Faperfor the next Meeting of theCabinet.-IB- 11. The Prime Minister said he wished to loseno time in putting in hand the examination of thevarious questions arising out the Economicsection of the Summary of Proceedings of theImperial Conference, 19 30. He instructed theSecretary to place the matter on the Agenda atthe next Meet ins. o' the Cabinet . Round-Table That the Cabinet Committee on theConference, Indian Round-Table conference should meet on the following day,Tuesday, November 18th, in the(Previous Prime Minister's Room at the reference: House of Commons, at 5 p.m.Cabinet 67(30), Con-clusion 3 0) IJl' MEETINGICABINET ,13. The Cabinet agreed That their next Meeting should beheld on Wednesday, November 19th,at 4 p cm ., in the Prime Minister1sRoom, House of Commons, when thefollowing questions should beplaced on the Agenda Paper:-0UAL MINES NATIONAL INDUSTRIAL BOARD.PRESENT ECONOMIC SITUATION IN GREAT BRITAINECONOMICLITER IAL CONFERENCE. PROP CSED/CONFERENCEAT OTTAWA. PREPARATIONS FOR.THE GENERAL STOPPAGE OF 1926. THE POSITIONOP GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEES WHO TOOK PART in whitehall Gardens, S,iV.l,November IB, 19 30.
